title: little_women
script: Written by Greta Gerwig Based on the novel by Louisa May Alcott ii. 've had lots of troubles, so write jolly tales. - Louisa May Alcott iii. Note: Where there is simultaneous or quick dialogue in the script, there is a in the middle of the speaker's dialogue, representing where the next actor should begin. The following actor's line will be started with a to indicate that it is interrupting another line. When the text is in , it indicates that it is the past timeline, which begins in Winter of 1861. When the text is in , it indicates that it is the present timeline, which begins in Fall of 1868. Both timelines move forward from their origin point. . . . 1868. , our heroine, hesitates. In the half-light of a dim hallway, she exhales and prepares, her head bowed like a boxer about to go into the ring. She puts her hand on the doorknob. pause, and then, she opens it onto a disorderly room. It is full of men. Some sit with their feet up on the desks, higher than their hats, which they do not remove for her. They smoke and read, hardly noticing that she has walked in. Jo walks through the desks, looking for one in particular. (clearing her throat) Excuse me. . (the oldest, smokiest gentleman) looks at her. (') was looking for the Weekly Volcano office... wished to see Mr. Dashwood? Mr. Dashwood stares silently. (') (nervous, presenting pages) friend of mine desired me to offer a story, by her, she wrote it - she’d be glad to write more if this suits. He stands and extends his rough, large hand. She gives him the manuscript. . (turning the pages over) Not a first attempt, take it? No, sir; she has sold to “Olympic” and “Scandal” and got a prize for a tale in the “Blarney Stone Banner.” . prize? (weakly) Yes. 2. He now takes in Jo’s appearance and her mended clothes. . Sit. Jo sits, hands folded, trying to cover the ink stains. Mr. Dashwood reads her story with a pen in hand, gleefully crossing out and making notes, changes. Every time his pen scratches, Jo feels her heart breaking. She’s on the verge of tears when: . (') We’ll take this. (looking up) You will? . With alterations. It’s too long. She nods and he hands it back to her, page after page with her work crossed out. She examines it. You’ve cut - took care to have a few of my sinners repent. . The country just went through a war. People want to be amused, not preached at. Morals don’t sell nowadays. (pointedly) Perhaps mention that to your “friend.” Jo looks again at her completely altered story. What do you - that is, what compensation - . We pay twenty-five to thirty for things of this sort. We’ll pay twenty for that. (money over art) You can have it. Make the edits. Jo hands over the story, Mr. Dashwood hands over the money, business done. 3. (') (then) Should tell my, my friend that you’ll take another if she had one better than this? . We’ll look at it. Tell her to make it short and spicy. And if the main character’s a girl make sure she’s married by the end. (casually) Or dead, either way. Excuse me? But he’s on to the next bit of business. . What name would she like put to the story? Oh, yes - none at all if you please. He considers her. . Just as she likes, of course. Good morning, sir. Good day. . . . . 1868. The streets of New York. After the Civil War and at the brink of The Industrial Revolution. It is a city in the middle of becoming, the 20th century on the horizon. Horses, trolleys, young, old, black, white, immigrants, returning soldiers, factory workers, wealthy industrialists, fashionable women and poor mothers all crowd the streets. We find Jo (also becoming) sprinting down the street with utter joy. She has pulled up her skirts and is running full steam. Not lady-running, flat-out . For the joy of it. 4. ./. . . . 1868. Jo reading and walking at the same time, bounding two-at-atime up the steps of a large brownstone boarding house. She stoops to pick up a cat who suns herself on the steps. (to the cat) My Beth would like you very much. As Jo walks through the house, into the drawing room, she lets the cat down, and goes straight to the fireplace. She stands with her back to it, to warm herself, and produces a small notebook and begins to write. She is so engrossed with her writing that she doesn’t hear the boisterous group of college students and professors, men and a few women, when they descend upon the room. She just keeps writing, until: (..) Good afternoon, Miss March. Jo looks up from her notebook to see looking down at her. He speaks with a French accent, and, like all Europeans, seems to know something that we Americans don’t: (she straightens up) Good afternoon, Professor. You’re on fire. Thank you. (suddenly animated) You’re on fire! Jo suddenly notices that the back of her dress has caught on fire. In a panic, another woman of the group helps her and the dress is put out. Disaster is avoided, although not humiliation. (laughing) have the same habit, you see? 5. He shows her scorch marks on his jacket. Jo is about to laugh when, . , the landlady, bustles into the room: . Kitty and Minny are waiting! Jo looks up the stairs to see the two little girls prancing. My students need me. Always working. (joke-dramatically) Money is the end and aim of my mercenary existence. No one gets ink stains like yours just out of a desire for money. Jo feels the intense pleasure and pain of being seen by someone, of knowing that they know you. (embarrassed, retreating) Well my sister Amy is in Paris, and until she marries someone obscenely wealthy, it’s up to me to keep the family afloat. Goodbye. (staring up after her) Goodbye. . . . . 1868. , an angelic 20-year-old with golden curls, is painting a staged scene, along with a few other young artists. It is a classic scene of two young men and a young woman at a picnic, and Amy is rendering it realistically, imitating the 18th & 19th century painters she loved. She looks at the painting of the young man next to her. He is doing something radically different - the paint is obvious, the colors are bright and un-life-like, space is flattened. It is not meant to be realistic: it is the beginning of modernism. She looks back at her own piece and realizes that she might have missed the moment that she came here to master. 6. Perhaps she’s already passed before her time. She continues working, troubled. . . . 1868. Amy rides in an open air carriage with , reading a letter from home. Everyone in Paris is out. Aunt March is only happy when she’s complaining, and she’s in excellent form this morning. It is the place to see and be seen and Amy March is doing both excellently. The decadents have ruined Paris, if you ask me. These French women couldn’t lift a hairbrush. No response from Amy. (') ! said, “These French women couldn’t lift a hairbrush.” Oh yes! Very true, Aunt March. Don’t humor me, girl. What do they write, your troublemaking family? Mother doesn’t say anything about Beth. feel should go back but they all say “stay.” You can do nothing if you go back. The girl is sick, not lonely. Amy gives her a hard look. (') And you shouldn’t go home until you and Fred Vaughn are properly engaged. Amy blushes and puts the letter away. Yes, and until ’ve completed all of my painting lessons, of course. Aunt March looks at her, momentarily confused. 7. What? Oh, yes, yes. Of course. Amy looks at all the passers-by. She sees a somber young man, tall and dark and looking down as he walks. Suddenly! ! ! ! Abandoning her primness, she launches out of the carriage and runs, nearly knocking people over. This is Theodore Laurence, , a 26-year-old without a sense of direction, like most 26-year-olds. They hug joyously and un-self-consciously: ! You’re so /grown up! /You wrote you’d come to the hotel! looked for you and couldn’t find /you anywhere! /You didn’t look hard enough! Maybe just didn’t recognize you, you’ve become so beaut/iful. (making a face) /Please don’t. thought you liked that sort of thing! . Where’s your Grandfather? Still in Germany. ’m on my own, traveling and /having fun. (teasing him) /and drinking and gambling and flirting... Don’t tell your mother! Are you chasing some young girl across Europe? (darkening) No. 8. (dropping her playfulness) ’m... couldn’t believe Jo turned you down. ’m so sorry. (crisp) Don’t be, Amy. ’m not. (..) ! ! ! (to Laurie) Oh, Aunt March! Laurie gallops over, and jumps into the carriage, kissing her: Aren’t we fine, /Ma’am. / ! He kisses her again, grinning. Il faut ! Allons-y! Aunt March attempts to get the carriage to leave, and Laurie is thrown off while Amy is thrown in. (calling after Laurie) Come to the New Year’s Party! It’s a ball and everyone will be there, including Fred - Pick me up at the hotel at eight - the Chavain! Dress for festivities! Top hats and silks! will! ’ll wear my best silk! Laurie turns and continues his heartbroken stroll, as Amy looks at him. She turns back to Aunt March. It’s Laurie! know. Amy turns around to get one last look at Laurie. She loves him, as she’s always loved him. 9. . . . 1868. , beautiful but with the melancholy of yearning emanating from her, is browsing the silks with Sallie Moffat, a rich young woman who possesses an air of casual boredom that comes from never having to work for what you have. (to the clerk) Twenty yards of the blue silk as well as the pink. Someone will be by for it later. She looks over at Meg, who touches a beautiful grey silk: (') Oh Meg! That would look so lovely on you. know just the dressmaker to send you to. You’ll be the prettiest wife in Concord. Oh no, John needs a new coat for winter and Daisy and Demi need new clothes and -- -- and his wife needs a new dress. (trying to hide her embarrassment) can’t... it’s, just can’t. He’ll be so pleased with how you look that he’ll forget all about the expense. (equivocating) don’t suppose it’s such an extravagance. Will twenty yards do? (deciding) Yes. Thank you. And Meg watches, delighted but fighting guilt, as the beautiful fabric is cut. 10. . ’ . . 1868. From inside a modest rural cottage, Meg emerges, wiping her hands and muttering to herself. (ashamed) Fifty dollars, what was thinking? She sees her two 3-year-olds, a boy and a girl, and , playing in the yard. She sits down to watch them, feeling both grateful and trapped. They run up to her. Mommy -- mommy! They fall into her arms, she accepts them and then sends them off to play again. We hear sounds a beautiful Bach piano sonata being played... . / . . 1868. ... the music grows louder as we see empty rooms of the childhood home -- the attic, the dining room, the stairs. Finally we find , alone at the piano. She stops playing suddenly, as if in pain. Then she takes a deep breath, feels the sunlight on her hand, and stretches it out. (..) Beth! Beth? She doesn’t respond. . . . 1868. Shakespeare’s Twelfth Night unfolds on stage. Jo is in the back, the cheap standing-room. She’s so wrapped up that she moves in until she’s practically leaning over the railing. It’s the scene where Viola (dressed as a man) seduces Olivia. ...That you do think you are not what you are. Then think you right, am not what am! Friedrich watches the play from his own, proper, seat. At a certain point, he sees Jo, and then watches her watching the play, her delight making him smile. 11. . . . 1868. The audience flows out of the theatre into the lobby. Jo, still in her theatrical reverie, spots Friedrich. She freezes, not moving, not wanting to be seen. She then follows behind the band of friends, drawn to them in spite of herself. . . . 1868. It is a rowdy and raucous crowd, drinking and dancing. Jo walks through the crowd, taking it in, watching Friedrich. He knows everyone and can speak half a dozen languages. Another man young, speaking a language Jo doesn’t know, offers his hand for the dance. ’m sorry, only speak English... Come dance! He pulls her into the dance, and she does her best to follow along. It’s whirling and loud and wild. Before long, she finds herself paired with Friedrich and all selfconsciousness leaves her. She is part of the night and the room and the music and she throws herself into movement, and we are taken back to.... . . . . & ’ . 1861. ...the sisters, all together again in the past, in the snowglobe of girlhood and memory that is ever present but forever gone, are in a flurry of getting ready for a holiday party. know just who ’ll dance with! Who will you dance with, Jo? You know never dance. can’t dance. Why can’t we all go to the party?! It’s not fair! Meg’s hair is covered in papers, and Jo manipulates a pair of hot tongs. Meg struggles to get on a pair of slippers. 12. Just wear your regular /shoes. (forcing it) /These fit last winter! Amy puts on jewels and rouge and tries to shape her nose. My nose will simply not look refined. (to no-one) like your nose. (reaching to Jo) Now, Jo -- -- don’t touch me, thanks! already feel ridiculous don’t want to look it! You could be pretty if you tried. Don’t want to, won’t do it. don’t want to go but wish could hear all the music. ’ll keep it all in my head and try to sing it for you when get home. Jo goes back to working on Meg’s hair. Beth watches Jo handle the tongs, amazed and slightly worried: Ought they to smoke /like that? (confident) /It’s the dampness drying. What a queer smell - it’s like... burnt feathers. There, now you’ll see a perfect little ringlet. 13. Jo removes the tongs, and a burnt clump of hair follows. Jo screams and Meg screams because Jo screams. (gasps, half delighted) You’re /ruined! /Why is her hair off? Meg, ’m so sorry! (looking in the mirror) What have you done?! /Marmee ’m spoilt! can’t go! My hair! /’m sorry! You shouldn’t have asked me to do it! ruin everything! . ' ’ . . . 1861. Meg and Jo walk down the hallway at the Gardiner’s very fancy party, the party already in full swing. Meg is chastising Jo: Don’t stare, don’t put your hands behind your back, don’t say Christopher Columbus, don’t say Capital, don’t shake hands, don’t whistle -- Meg is immediately pulled away. Meg March! You look so pretty! Sallie Moffat, at that moment Sallie Gardiner, pulls Meg away from Jo, who is left standing awkwardly. Meg... Meg seems to put on another face and attitude, more grown up and elegant. Jo fades away into the back of the party. . ’ ’ . . . 1861. Jo, 16, miserable, glumly watches the dancers. She pulls at a string on her dress. She catches Meg’s eyes, 17, laughing with her dance partner, and pleads with her to leave. Meg aggressively shakes her head, and Jo sighs, resigned. very large red-headed boy makes a beeline for Jo - in her terror, she looks for an escape. 14. She slips behind a curtain, and walking backwards, she nearly sits on Theodore Laurence (!), Laurie, a very serious looking 17-year-old boy. Dear me, didn’t know any one /was here! (rising) /Don’t mind me; stay, if you like. won’t disturb you? Not at all; don’t know many people, and felt rather strange at first, you know. So do . They stand there, unsure of what to do, both shy. Miss March, isn’t it? Yes, Mr. Laurence, but ’m not Miss March, ’m only Jo. And ’m not Mr. Laurence, ’m only Laurie. Their first burst of conversation has run it’s course, and they smile at each other, standing in the not-unpleasant awkwardness of meeting. Don’t you dance? don’t know how you do things here yet - you see, ’ve spent most of my life in Europe. ! That’s ! (she catches herself) shouldn’t use words like that. Says who? 15. Meg. (nodding sympathetically) 	Maybe after the holidays then. . - The old woman carries her manuscript haltingly down a subway hall. She stops to catch her breath, then continues and passes several archway with letters printed above them. When she arrives at one topped by an , she slips a card in a slot. plastic molded chair drops into the archway. She sits in the chair; it rises. . - The woman is still in the chair as it slips gracefully into a line of chairs shooting through a glass tube. The other chairs are peopled with commuters. We stay with the woman as she and the others travel over New York City in the tube. There are hundreds of these commuter tubes crisscrossing the skyline. The woman glances at the manuscript in her lap. It's called: Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind This serves as the movie's opening title. script: . There is a gunshot. crow screams. fluttering of wings. : . - Bird's-eye view. We circle lazily above the forest. Through a break in the trees, we catch an occasional glimpse of a prostrate form on the ground. As the circling camera gets closer we see that the form is a human body. : - 'm not sorry. bead of sweat trickles down her cheek. Then: a blinding flash of light obliterates her face. : - am sorry. tear wells in Puff's eye and runs down his face. Another blinding flash of light. : - don't even know what sorry means anymore. As Nathan speaks, a trickle of blood drips down his face from his out-of-frame forehead. Another blinding flash of light. : . - It's a frenetic hand-held shot as Lila is pulled from a police car and dragged into the precinct house. Cameras flash. Reporters shout questions. Lila attempts to shield her face from view, but she is handcuffed and can only manage to hunch her shoulders. : . - ratty interrogation room. Institutional green walls. Beat-up file cabinets. Dark. bit of fluorescent light spills in through the frosted glass door. Lila, thirties, sits at the end of a long table. reel-to-reel tape recorder whirs in front of her. She is smoking. Three fat, mean-looking cops sit in shadows at the other end of the table. One of the cops eyes her lasciviously. Lila's hand shakes as she brings the cigarette to her mouth. 'm not sorry. So spend the rest of my life in jail. So what? 've been in jail my whole life anyway. jail of blood and tissue and coursing hormones... One of the cops sighs and massages the bridge of his nose. It's going to be a long night. ...a jail called the human body. The lascivious cop smiles lasciviously at Lila's reference to "human body." My soul held prisoner in this reeking, stench-ridden bag of bones and entrails. bag of feces and piss and fibroid cysts in my tits and precancerous moles on my sun-damaged back... The lascivious cop gags, then vomits on the floor. Lila drags on her cigarette, calmer now. At least now 'll be able to blame the state, not God, for my incarceration. : . - Puff, thirties, dirty, scraggly hair and beard but in a crisp business suit, testifies before a congressional committee. The auditorium is filled with reporters and spectators. Puff sits in front of a microphone, counsel at his side. He pours himself a glass of water, drinks, clears his throat, then speaks: stentorian, confident. am sorry, gentlemen, sorry for all of us. Your's is a complicated, sad world. This is a revelation to the assembled crowd. People whisper to each other. And never knew that. was living a life of simplicity, of purity, when was ripped out of my Eden and immersed in this harshness. Some would argue that the life was living was not a human life at all. And, gentlemen, don't have any clever retort. am not a philosopher. The only thing know is that am sorry, sorry for my expulsion from Eden, sorry for my Lila rotting in her jail cell, and sorry for Nathan... rotting in his grave. : . - Nathan, thirties, in a white robe, sits alone at a white table. Everything is white except for an oozing bullet wound in Nathan's temple. don't even know what sorry means anymore. It's odd. When was alive knew -- maybe it was all knew -- but here sorry is meaningless. Love is meaningless. Jealousy is meaningless. Ambition is meaningless. Everything that motivated my every breath while was alive is meaningless now. (beat) guess that's how can be sure 'm really dead. : . - Lila watches the slowly churning tape recorder reels, fixated. The cop who vomited is mopping it up. The other two are sipping coffee. Lila talks. My story begins when was twelve. (checks watch) Jesus. : . - It's got that faded, "memory" look. Twelve year old Lila hurries home from school, books clutched to her chest. Other kids walk along the street in pairs or groups, laughing and chatting. Lila walks alone, a worried scowl on her face. (..) Something terrible happened when was twelve. : . ' - Colors are still muted. It looks to be somewhere in the early 70's based on the preponderance of Bay City Rollers posters on the wall. Twelve year old Lila enters the room, closes the door, locks it, rattles the doorknob to make sure that the door is really locked. She draws the shades. She pulls some t-shirts from her dresser drawer and stuffs them into the space between the bottom of the door and the floor. (..) (muffled) Hey, no fair! Drop dead, Eric. Lila stands nervously in front of the full-length mirror on her closet door. She takes a deep breath and begins to unbutton her shirt, watching herself carefully in the mirror. (..) Something terrible started to happen to my body when was twelve. My mother said because of it would never be able to get a man, so should get used to the idea of dedicating my life to the pursuit of knowledge, or religion... or whatever. Lila's shirt is now unbuttoned. She pulls it open. She is wearing a training bra over the very beginning of breast buds. On the chest above the bra, and on her stomach below it, is hair. Dark curly hair. She stares at it, touches it cautiously. Then she starts to cry. She crouches into a ball and weeps. (..) The doctor said... : . ' - Old fashioned office. Twelve year old Lila sits on the examination table, her shirt off. An elderly male doctor touches the hair, fingers it. Her mother looks on. (to the mother) It's hormonal. Nature is a funny and complex thing. It could get worse with time. Young Lila turns to the camera. By the time was twenty looked like an ape. : . - The cop who vomited, gags again. Lila stares at him. Her face is hard, blank. She stubs out her cigarette. : . - Puff testifies before the committee. don't think there's anyone in the world who doesn't know by now that was raised in the wilderness by an ape. Well, to be fair, by a man who thought himself an ape, but it amounts to the same thing gentlemen, does it not? : . - . He runs crazily towards the camera, waving his arms, puffing out his cheeks. (..) He had been committed the previous year after applying one too many times at our local zoo for the job of "apprentice ape." Puff's father passes a newspaper vending machine, stops, goes back and examines the headline. It reads: President Kennedy Assassinated. Puff's father looks heavenward and clutches at his temples in despair. (..) My father saw what the human race had come to while he was... in captivity. He felt something had to be done to create a better world. : . - Puff's father climbs out a second story window with a small bundle in his arms. He runs off into the night. (..) He stole little me from my mother, his ex-wife, and raised me, with love and tenderness and respect, as an ape like himself. : . - Puff looks pointedly at the congressman. Apes don't assassinate their presidents, gentlemen. The congressmen are shamed: they look down, they take notes, they mumble instructions to the assistants seated behind them. : . - An adult Puff and his now older father sit on the forest floor and pick bugs off each other and eat them. (..) Until quite recently believed myself to be an ape, although didn't know specifically what type. Apes don't think in terms of type. : . - Puff testifies. It might be argued, gentlemen, that apes don't even know that they are apes. In retrospect, however, 'd say that was a pygmy chimp. Puff holds up an illustration of a pygmy chimp. Several reporters run from the room: a scoop! : . - Nathan talks to nobody in particular. have to say always hated apes. Of course don't any longer. don't even know what hate means now. But while alive, hated apes. blame my parents. mean, don't blame them. don't know what blame is, really, anymore, but think they influenced me in my ape-hating tendencies. : . - Faded colors. Ten year old Nathan in a bow tie and shortpanted suit walks along with his uptight, British parents. They arrive at the ape pen. Nathan is excited. He jumps up and down. The apes jump up and down also. Monkeys! Look, mama, monkeys! (clamping down on his shoulder) Nathan, those are not monkeys. Those are apes. Mountain Gorillas to be precise. Nathan, his father, and the other zoo patrons look on curiously, a little frightened. Nathan's mother chooses to ignore it. And furthermore... Tell him, Harold. (distracted) Uh... (then by rote) We must never act like apes, son. For you see, The ape is our closest biological relative -- specifically the pygmy chimp. (holds up the same illustration of a pygmy chimp that Puff showed the congressional committee) single chromosome separates us. But you know what truly separates us from the apes, what makes us better than apes? No, papa. What? Culture. Civilization. Refinement. If we do not have these as humans, then we might as well be living in pens and throwing our feces about, masturbating in public... (beat, a reverie) ...sniffing red swollen female rump... Enough, Harold. : . - Lila lights a new cigarette with her spent one. She drags. Oh, had sexual urges. had the urge to merge, officers. Inside was 100% Grade female. (laughs derisively) But what self-loathing felt! Who would have someone as repulsive, as unladylike as me? did everything could to shield the world from this repulsiveness. : . - Stockings hang over the shower curtain rod. The window shade is drawn. Towels are stuffed in the space under the door. twenty year old naked Lila is covered with shaving cream, face to feet. She is shaving. There is a pounding on the door. (..) Lila, what are you doing in there? need to get ready for my date. Nothing! 'll be out in a minute! The door opens. Lila freezes. Look, 'll just... (stops in her tracks when she sees Lila) What the...? Lila is mortified. : . - Lila is sitting in her bathrobe on her bed and staring out the window. There is a bit of shaving cream behind her ear. Her roommate runs back and forth getting ready for her date. don't know why you didn't tell me about this. It's embarrassing, okay? It's not so bad. (beat) So, it just keeps growing? Yeah, Natalie. It's hair. It grows. Well, don't jump down my throat. 'm just trying to help. How is that helping, Natalie? How exactly? Look, if you're going to be like that... You should be appreciative that 'm interested. Why, because 'm a freak and you are beautiful, and you are being nice enough to come down to my freak, nonbeautiful level and act concerned about my repulsive troubles? (pegged) You're fucked up, Lila. (out the door) Why don't you fucking try electrolysis or something? Figure it out for chrissake. The door slams. Lila hugs her knees to her chest. (..) At sixty dollars an hour, electrolysis was not a feasible solution. explored my alternatives. : . - Twelve year old Lila walks sadly through an art museum. she looks at various old portraits of men. She studies their facial hair. When she turns a corner, she is shocked to see a large Renaissance painting of a naked woman entirely covered with fur. She hurries to it. She looks at the placard next to the painting. It is a painting of Mary Magdalene. (..) remember once coming across a painting of Mary Magdalene entirely covered with fur. guess that's where got the idea that maybe the Catholic Church might be a place that encouraged excessive hair growth in its women. . - Lila, in a nun's habit, is on her knees praying.
